item.title: Letter From Europe: In Syria, Advocates Step In to Sift for Truth
item.description: More and more, nongovernmental organizations are stepping in for journalists to report in far-off and dangerous lands.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: After Rout in German Elections, Social Democrats Consider Coalition With Merkel
item.description: The defeated Social Democrats convened to decide whether to enter into talks with Chancellor Angela Merkel’s conservatives over a possible coalition, and what price to extract from her if they do.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: India Ink: A Stranger on Lenox Avenue
item.description: The attack on Prabhjot Singh, an assistant professor at Columbia University, is jarring because Harlem has a deep history of solidarity between various communities.
item.dc:creator: By MANAN AHMED ASIF
item.media:credit: Michael Appleton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prabhjot Singh, an assistant professor of international affairs at Columbia University, at a press conference in New York on Monday.

item.title: Japan’s Leader Gives No Ground in Islands Dispute
item.description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan said he was open to dialogue with China about disputed islands in the South China Sea but that Japan owns them.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: U.N. Investigates New Alleged Chemical Attacks in Syria
item.description: Inspectors were looking into reports that chemical weapons were used seven times, including three after the Aug. 21 attack that set off an international crisis.
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: Sept. 27
item.description: Sania Mirza, Indian tennis player, in action during a women’s doubles match in Tokyo, Japan.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Sania Mirza, Indian tennis player, right, and Cara Black of Zimbabwe in action during a women's doubles semifinal match at the Toray Pan Pacific Open tournament in Tokyo, Japan.

item.title: U.N. Climate Panel Endorses Ceiling on Global Emissions
item.description: Top climate scientists on Friday embraced an upper limit on greenhouse gases while warning that it is likely to be exceeded within decades if efforts to curb emissions are not rapidly accelerated.
item.dc:creator: By JUSTIN GILLIS
item.media:description: Ban Ki-moon, the secretary general, addressed the United Nation's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change on Friday.

item.title: Reporting Iran’s News, but Speaking for One Side
item.description: In Iran’s news media landscape, which is divided into two camps, the hard-liners and reformists, the semiofficial Fars agency has emerged in recent years as the most influential conservative voice.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: U.N. Rights Panel Increases Pressure on Syria
item.description: The Human Rights Council on Friday stepped up pressure on President Bashar al-Assad to allow greater access for humanitarian aid and for war crimes investigators.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Have-Nots Squeezed and Stacked in Hong Kong
item.description: In a city with some of the highest living costs in the world, those at the bottom of the income ladder increasingly resort to cupboardlike living spaces, a dozen or more to an apartment.
item.dc:creator: By BETTINA WASSENER and GRACE TSOI

item.title: India Ink: Rahul Gandhi Opposes Ordinance Seeking to Protect Convicted Lawmakers
item.description: Rahul Gandhi, Congress Party’s vice president, opposes an ordinance seeking reprieve for convicted lawmakers prepared by India’s governing coalition led by his party.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: Rahul Gandhi, vice president of the Congress Party, speaking at the press club in New Delhi on Friday.

item.title: Bus Bombing in Pakistan Kills at Least 17 Government Employees
item.description: The bombing, which left more than 40 people wounded, was the second major attack in a week in the Peshawar area in northwestern Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: Scores Feared Trapped in Collapse of Mumbai Building
item.description: The collapse of a five-story residential building on Friday comes as concern has grown about lax standards and endemic corruption in the construction industry in India.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS and NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: Rescue workers lifted a woman from the rubble at the site of a collapsed residential building in Mumbai on Friday.

item.title: India Ink: Ahead of India-Pakistan Talks, Militants Kill as Many as 12 in Indian-Controlled Kashmir
item.description: Three men dressed in Indian Army uniforms attacked a police station and an army base, officials said, just days before a planned meeting between leaders of India and Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Indian soldiers took cover Thursday as an army base was attacked in the Samba district of Indian-controlled Kashmir.

item.title: U.S. and Turkey to Create Fund to Stem Extremism
item.description: The $200 million fund aims to undercut the ideological and recruiting appeal of jihadists in places like Somalia, Yemen and Pakistan, State Department officials said.
item.category: Global Fund for Community Engagement and Resilience
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Rebels in Mali Suspend Peace Deal With Government
item.description: Separatists in the north accused the government of failing to begin the process of releasing prisoners as called for under the June peace accord.
item.category: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Iranian President Softens Condemnation of Holocaust
item.description: President Hassan Rouhani appeared to walk his condemnation of the Holocaust back a notch on Thursday, one day after he provoked a politically fraught uproar.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sudan Erupts in Deadly Protests as Gas Prices Rise
item.description: The police and activists differed on how many Sudanese were killed in protests this week after the government lifted gasoline subsidies, raising the price of gas and other commodities.
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH
item.media:description: Protesters toppled pumps in Khartoum this week after the government lifted gasoline subsidies.

item.title: The Lede: What Iran’s President Said, Is Said to Have Said and Says He Said
item.description: In an interview broadcast by CBS News on Thursday, Iran’s new president, Hassan Rouhani, rejected accusations that he had not clearly acknowledged the historical reality of the Holocaust in remarks to CNN earlier this week.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: U.N. Deal on Syrian Arms Is Milestone After Years of Inertia
item.description: In the most significant diplomatic initiative of the Syrian civil war, five key nations have agreed on a resolution saying Syria must give up its chemical weapons, but the statement lacks the threat of force.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, left, Iran's foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, and Catherine Ashton, Europe's chief foreign policy official, during a meeting Thursday.

item.title: Rouhani, Blunt and Charming, Pitches a Moderate Iran
item.description: Amid his fervent diplomatic theater this week, it was at times hard to tell whether Iran’s president, Hassan Rouhani, was a genuinely transformative leader.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran, center, at the United Nations. He has had a flurry of speeches, interviews and meetings.

item.title: Chile Hunt for Justice Winds Up as Enigma
item.description: A former American Navy captain accused of involvement in the murders of two Americans after the 1973 coup may have been right under the noses of the investigators seeking his extradition.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By PASCALE BONNEFOY

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Charges Over Auschwitz Role
item.description: German prosecutors said Thursday that they had charged a 93-year-old man with being an accessory to murder over what they said was his role as an Auschwitz death camp guard.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: As Merkel Is Showered in Glory, Hollande Trudges Through Drizzle
item.description: President François Hollande of France is struggling at home, while across the border in Germany, Chancellor Angela Merkel is having a much nicer time of it these days.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Companies Admit They Fixed Prices of Car Parts
item.description: The companies, all based in Japan, agreed to pay $740 million in fines on federal charges of fixing prices on parts like radiators sold to automakers in the United States.
item.dc:creator: By JACLYN TROP
item.media:description: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. outlined the price-fixing investigation at a press conference on Thursday.
